34548993.review:
In my opinion, Pajama Sam was the best series Humongous ever made, featuring imaginative settings, witty writing, and clever gameplay. Now, I personally think that Pajama Sam 2 isn't quite as good as the first and third games in the series, but that isn't saying much because this is an excellent adventure game. In this entry, Sam decides that he's had enough of a scary thunderstorm, and sets out to put a stop to Thunder and Lightning, who turn out to be sisters in charge of the world's weather. Finding a massive complex called World Wide Weather, he sneaks inside and has an accident that sends the weather operations into turmoil, and now he must find the four missing parts to bring the weather factories back on line, before Thunder and Lightning lose their jobs.

One point of criticism I have is that the big conundrum in the game  is all Sam's fault. That doesn't hurt my enjoyment of the game, but I don't like it when the main objective of game is undoing the protagonist's mistake. It would have been better if Sam had arrived just after things went awry, lending some mystery to what caused the problem; maybe Foster Boondoggle, who never appears in-person in the game, could secretly be the perpetrator who we confront at the end. 

Otherwise, the game is just what you'd expect from a Pajama Sam game: exploring a boy's wild imagination, populated by characters who are mostly living furniture and in a fun, nonsensical setting. The game world is a mix of industrial and corporate environments, contrasting with both PJ Sam 1 and 2. You'd think this would be boring, but the game is so imaginative that it's every bit as fun to explore as the other games. Something else that just occurred to me is the first three PJ Sam games each occur at different times of the day: PJ Sam 1 is at night, 2 is during the day, and 3 is during twilight. Having a fourth game kind of screws up that pattern, but oh well. 

All in all, this is a great game for kids, and also for any fan of adventure games. In fact, I'd recommend any of the Pajama Sam or Spy Fox games for any adventure gamer, regardless of age.

33941294.review: Purchased this game for nostalgia. Apparently my problem solving skills were a lot more advanced at five than they are now.

33309970.review:
The best direct-to-video children's movies ever made came on CD.

Ron Gilbert, video gaming's Bill Watterson, channels ACTUAL Bill Watterson with his less-precocious non-photocopy-blue Calvin whose Hobbes is an entire universe of talking objects. Full of wit, wackiness and wonder, the Pajama Sam series (apart from Atari's infamous fourth game) oozes with character from every pore. Being a Humongous adventure game, it's part point-and-click and part Living Book, with tons of animations even adults will enjoy wasting their time with.

These games aren't just too good for children. They're too good for adults. They are too pure for this wretched world. Atari tried to taint them with Life is Rough When You Lose Your Stuff and they failed. You don't deserve these games. Then again, nobody does, so you might as well buy it anyway.

33063023.review: Unlike with Freddi Fish, which was my favourite franchise as a kid, I've first encountered Pajama Sam not long ago and was immediately charmed by its great art and the very idea of a young kid who travels through the worlds of his imagination, always based on the most recent events in his life. After playing the games I can only say - what a shame that I didn't have them as a kid! I'm positive I would fall in love with them, because they have everything you want from a kids' game - a good message, funny and memorable characters (especially Sam who's just the cutest kid ever), an environment you can interact with, minigames and, surprisingly, very smart sense of humour. If you have children, I stongly recommend that you play Pajama Sam series with them, and if not - just try it yourself, it may very well return you to your own childhood. It sure did that for me.

28692062.review:
This was a nice revisit to a game I played as a child. I wouldn't classify this as a edutainment-esque game to parents; its a point and click adventure game with a lot of quirky interations with the environment. Throughout many of their games Humungous Entertainment creates fun colorful environments that children will find entertaining. I played games by them when I was about 6-10, and that is the best captive audience for these games. Adults can find entertainment in this as well, but just keep in mind its a game made for children.

Sadly the game is a bit dated with the graphics and animations not holding up well to todays standards and the voice acting is sub-par; but its not like this was meant to be a triple A title. I did find some of the jazzy music to be pretty capturing though. 


Id give it a 8/10, feel free to check out other Humungous Entertainment games like Freddy Fish or the other games in the Pajama Sam series. The asking price for the game is pretty fair.

20340691.review:
As I've looked through a lot of the Humongous library on Steam, I've also seen a lot of fans who grew up with the games (including myself) giving high reviews to this game. Like 10/10's and what not. To be frank, I like these games as well. But are they absolute perfect? Hell, no. Not by my standards at least. The best Humongous game was probably Pajama Sam 1, and I'd probably give that a 7/10 or 8/10. But what about Pajama Sam 2? Ah yes, dear reader. What ABOUT Pajama Sam 2? 

The game does have a lot of color and charm. It looks nice , and there are plenty of nice jokes only adults would get, as usual. However, the biggest dip in the game would be the story. In the original Pajama Sam, the story had just enough control in the player's hands to make the story build to an ultimate climax no matter how they got their objects. In Pajama Sam 2, the same thing is present, but out of nowhere, after you put in the third missing piece, a new story element pops out of nowhere in the appearance of a new character that is there purely for the reason of building tension. What was interesting about the tension in Pajama Sam 1, is it was shown through the visuals and the build-up both inside and outside of the story. Everything was connected, but detached enough for you to have your own adventure.

And I think the biggest reason that the story just isn't that good is because of the set-up. Pajama Sam 1 had the point of the story be that you don't need to be afraid of the dark. Simple but still good. And the story built up to that overall point being the main message. In Pajama Sam 2, Sam instantly finds out, "Hey! My fears are just controlled by a couple ladies in a sky-factory! There's nothing to be afraid of!", leaving nothing to be learned but just having the player wait until the ending finally arrives.

Pajama Sam 2 is, by no means, a bad game. If you liked the charm of the last game, it's still here. At least that hasn't been killed off.... right Atari?  But Pajama Sam 1 was so good, and I think Humongous tried to bring back the magic by doing a lot of the same things from the first game all over again. Sam overcoming his fears, the room with four questions, the lost items scattered across the world. It's all the same. Hell, Pajama Sam 2 loves to reference the first game a lot as well. You run into the carrot, some of the portraits have characters from Pajama Sam 1 in them for no reason, and there are binoculars for you to go look at the Land of Darkness. Pajama Sam 2 is basically Humongous saying, "It worked in the first game. Let's just do it again!" And I don't like that.

Pajama Sam 2 is a young superhero's quest to fix all the weather machines he inadvertently disrupted on his way to the top.
I played this game numerous times when I was a kid. And now thanks to Night Dive, I can play it forever. Not too long ago I bought all the Humongous games on sale for $25, so now whenever a new old HE! game comes out on Steam, I get those too. And since most of these games are compatable and bundled with ScummVM, I can play them with high-res pixel filters that make the games look better than ever, especially on HD monitors. If you were a child of the 90's like me, you'll have played this game, and if you didn't, now's as good a time as ever. 10/10

17669740.review:
Pajama Sam 2: Thunder and Lightning Aren't So Frightening truly is a work of art. I don't mean that lightly. The way it's animated plus its music gives it that title in my book. I can find myself exploring one room for an hour, maybe even hours at a time. The frustration of not finding the solution is filled with relaxation and calmness because of the ambient music. The way the worlds are crafted is truly mindblowing. They had a system in which you had to perfect a puzzle to earn a new area, and you would use that new area to earn more puzzles. In layman's terms, to earn more rooms, you had to perfect current puzzles. They ditched that and added the ability to google the solutions. I'm very glad they added this system and was skeptical about buying it. But now that I did buy it, I do not regret it even for a second. One thing I really love about this game is how you don't have to unlock the first room. In a sense, this game is open world. That sense is that many rooms are available to you, and you can choose whether you want to advance into more challenging rooms, or stay where you're at. To get an S in completion, you have to play every variation.

Another thing I absolutely enjoy about Pajama Sam 2: Thunder and Lightning Aren't So Frightening is its expasive community. There are lots of flash games for you to sharpen your skills on, and lots of people who can set a good example. I'm sure most of the people who get best times on all the levels have a Youtube channel, so you can probably catch them there. The community may or not be active, but it sure is good and friendly.

Overall, in terms of gameplay, music, artstyle, animation, and difficulty (it's not an easy game, but it's not that hard of a game either. It just depends on how much you want to play it), I rate this game:

10/10
BUY THIS GAME.

16869396.review:
If you would dare to look at Pajama Sam 2 and say to yourself, 'Well, it's a sequel, it can't be quite as good,' you need to immediately rethink all of your life decisions and then play Pajama Sam 2. While there are some slight changes here and there to keep the game feeling fresh, Pajama Sam 2 is packed with all the distinct features that made the first game so amazing: more pointing and clicking, more item collecting and more existential journeys of self-discovery. Instead of collecting socks, Sam collects a large variety of puzzle pieces, which is likely symbolic of the courage and morality he must piece together in order to confront his crippling fear of thunder and lightning. Speaking of puzzles, Pajama Sam 2 is like a puzzle with every piece in its proper place: with its moving story, well-crafted characters and exciting gameplay, this game feels incredibly polished and complete. Throughout its development, the geniuses at Humongous Entertainment must have known they had a masterpiece on their hands.

If I had to give this game a score, I would give it a 10/10 with a complimentary smiley face.

16266660.review:
Sometimes you're the thunder, and sometimes you're pajama sam. This game made me realize, and begin to come to terms with, the subjectivity of our reality. Everything is a projection of the collective concious, and Humongous Entertainment has been a spiritual guide in my journey to that epiphany. 
Great game. Best played in combinaion with psychedellics.

15135380.review: Pajama Sam is back and this time he is over coming his fear of thunder and lightning. In order to accomplish his goal he goes to his attic to "visit" the weather company high up in the clouds. Upon his visit, he accidently causes all of the weather machines to malfunction and the fate of the weather conditions of the world rests upon Sam. Like the first game, it's a simple point and click adventure that is very easy to navigate. The characters in this installment are very lively and very appealing to look at. I can just imagine the creative process for these games. The jokes are very clever and will guarantee that you will laugh at least once upon one playthrough. While there's plenty of areas to click on to entertain you for hours. If you love the first game, then this one is a must buy. Kids as well as adults will favor this game as a great sequal to one of Humongous Entertainment's most popular characters.

14237409.review: I really enjoyed this despite not liking superhero games. I had never played it before & despite pretending to be an adult I found myself stuck on a few puzzles. Which I always love whilst playing an Adventure Game. I made sure to get my moneys worth and click on everything on the backdrop. One of things I love about some Humongous Games is that you can replay the game and get a few different puzzles that you won't have seen before. The only things I didn't like was that one character would repeat the same dialogue every time you walked past it, which grated on me. However you can press the spacebar I think, to shut it up. Especially if you've never played it before, like whimsical silliness & still have child-like mind.

13727632.review:
Pajama Sam 2: Thunder and Lightning Aren't So Frightening Review - Raymond KT


This game is what I played when I got home from preschool all I did was play this game. Even today i still play it from time to time. This game is the best game for younger children I've ever seen

If your child has played beginning level software and is ready to move on to more advanced gameplay, Humongous Entertainment's Pajama Sam series (and Freddie Fish and Putt-Putt as well) are an excellent choice. These titles take the cognitive tasks up a notch as children must accumulate specific items, navigate a number of locations, and use their problem-solving skills to help new friends and achieve larger goals. Along the way, funny and lovable Pajama Sam will meet a number of nice characters, visit a variety of interesting locations and play mini-games as he completes the larger task of helping to fix the interesting and entertaining weather machine. Along the way he will solve a lot of smaller puzzles. Specifics change if you start a new game, and you will want to play with your child a few times before they'll be able to enjoy it on their own, so each game is good for hours of fun.

(Above Review from Amazon.ca)

approaches Captain Gelatin.

Pajama Man bursts out of the cosmic eraser box.

10649994.review: Childhood staple. Its quick, fun, and just a great game for kids.

10631414.review:
I loved this game as a kid, and I'm not ashamed to say I love it as an adult. It's humorous, witty, and delightfully clever in terms of plot, gameplay, and dialogue. Not going to lie, I think this game is even funnier as an adult than I ever did as a kid!

The best part is, it comes with a high replay value, due to the fact the game has several different scenarios to achieve the ending that it randomly loads each time you start the game.

10460199.review: Fun to play even for older kids, im 18 and had trouble figuring out what to do, LOL, some minor changes from its original release, but still fun to play, intersting to look at with beautiful animation and the nostalgia came back reminding me of my younger days playing this game at home.

10177244.review:
A great game from the past. If you ever want to relive your childhood again, then this is definitely a buy, I think you'll come to appreciate how wonderful this game now. 

10/10 for me

10172823.review: This game is what seperates man from God, for even the gods themselves cannot surmount the sheer power that emanates from the player's hands. This game grants you CONTROL over the elements: floods, tornadoes, blizzards, earthquakes,THUNDER AND LIGHTNING! Call upon THE SUN with a MERE CLICK. Summon FISSURES from devices AT HAND. BRING UPON THE SUFFERING OF MANKIND AS YOU--PAJAMA SAM--FEAR NOT LIGHTNING NOR THUNDER. YOU ARE GOD!!

10079529.review: This Game was my Childhood! Everyone must atleast play one HE game before they die. Humungous Entertainment has and wil always will be my Fav, Childhood Video game company (Well Mabey knowledge adventure also)

10022538.review:
This game doesn't take society's crap. Just like the first one.

Social taboo left and right. All from a blue kid's mind that probably doesn't even understand how complex he is.

20/4 you should play this.

10006873.review:
One of many Pajama Sam games I never played as a child.

This was lacking a few things: same bgm alternations throughout the game--pretty lack-a-daisy, the voice casting for lightning was a bit disappointing than what I imagined, game didn't feel that all engaging overall unlike the first one. Title was a bit misleading along with the prologue, thought it was to go against Thunder and LIghtning, like going after Darkness in the first game, not help them... then again...

Still, that's just minor things, and I'm being a bit nit-picky.

Still a good game for kids; they may not get much of the jokes or references right off the bat. Learn a few things about weather and how it works, along with a bit of economics... although that's very boring stuff so leave that to the carrot and the board of directors to discuss amongst themselves.

9994583.review:
If you've ever played the originals, play them again and you will cry tears of joy.
Pajama Sam is at it again, getting high as fuck and talking to clouds.
Game of my life right here, 10/10, would play again.
Nominated for test of time Steam award.
